page.text: Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)

text.b: City of Walla Walla Planning Commission

page.text: Public Hearing – 20 lot planned unit development preliminary
subdivision. 19 of the lots are proposed for single-family residential
homes and would be 6,000 sf or larger. The final lot is proposed to
be used for 45 detached condominium structures with shared
2464 SW Glacier Pl, Suite 110; Redmond, OR 97756
The property is located south of the County Fairgrounds at the
northeast corner of the intersection of Stevens Street and Lodge
Drive (APN 360732210061), in the RM zoning district, within the
The applicant is requesting approval of a planned unit development (PUD) that would contain 20
lots and would result in a maximum of 64 dwelling units. As proposed, 19 of the lots would contain
typical single-family residences, and the final lot would contain 45 detached small homes, ranging
in size from 400-1064 square feet. The small homes would have a shared parking lot in the center
of the parcel. The Applicant has presented that this type of small home development is an
“alternative to apartment living.” The applicant has proposed a PUD in order to receive more
The Walla Walla Urban Area Comprehensive Plan assigns the Residential land use designation to
the subject property. As noted above, the property is located within the RM- Residential Multi-
Family zoning district, and the Applicant has proposed two types of residential product types. This
is allowed through WWMC 19.26.010F in the RM district.
The property is located just south of the Walla Walla County Fairgrounds on the northeast corner of
the intersection of Stevens Street and Lodge Drive. The site is currently vacant and generally flat.
Stone Creek is located north/northwest of the proposal.
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
Adjacent uses are primarily low-density residential to the east and south. Property directly north is
zoned Highway Commercial. There are a few commercial businesses north of Stone Creek on W.
Tietan St. Further north, across Tietan is the County Fairgrounds and more medium to low density
residential development. Land west of Stevens St. is vacant and zoned RM.
On January 9, 2014, the City of Walla Walla Site Plan Review Committee (SPRC) met with the
Applicant, reviewed the proposed project and corresponding request for the planned unit
development. The following SPRC members were present at this meeting: Jon Maland, WWJCDA
Principal Planner; Lauren Prentice, WWJCDA Senior Planner; Jennifer Ballard, WWJCDA Associate
Planner; Barbara McKinney, Walla Walla County Public Works (addressing); Dave Collette,
WWJCDA Building Official; Dean Abrams, City of Walla Walla Engineering Divisions; and Tim
Thompson, City of Walla Walla Fire Department.
The SPRC findings and comments are contained within the summary letter, dated February 5, 2014,
which is included as an attachment to this staff report.
The Applicant prepared a State Environmental Policy Act (SEPA) Environmental Checklist. The City
of Walla Walla SEPA Responsible Official, WWJCDA Director Tom Glover, issued a final SEPA
Threshold Determination of Non Significance (DNS) on February 13 (file P13-093). A
Determination of Consistency was issued concurrently with the DNS.
A notice of application and a notice of public hearing were issued on this proposal as required by
WWMC Chapter 20.14. As of February 24, 2014 staff has only received one public comment: an
email from Carol McCormmach. This email is attached to the staff report.
Section 19.14.020B requires that the staff report stall determine whether the proposed preliminary
subdivision “conforms to policies, standards and accepted design principles” for the following
items. Staff analysis is provided below.
1. Consistency with the comprehensive plan and municipal code;
2. Appropriate provisions for the factors enumerated in RCW 58.17.100 within the proposed
3. Adequate means of ingress and egress to the proposed lots in accordance with the
4. Mitigation of probable adverse environmental impacts.

text.i: 1. WALLA WALLA URBAN AREA COMPREHENSIVE PLAN

page.text: Staff has reviewed the proposal against the goals and policies of the City of Walla Walla Urban Area
Comprehensive Plan and provides the following analysis.
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
Policy LU 1. The City is responsible for regulating the types, locations and densities of land uses
within its incorporated boundaries through the Comprehensive Plan and Zoning. Development
proposals are expected to be in compliance with and support the City’s adopted regulations. Each
development proposal should be reviewed based upon its compliance with the Comprehensive Plan
and existing zoning and insofar as it supports the following objectives:
Maintains or improves the quality of life.
Serves a range of transportation needs.
Protects natural, cultural, archaeological and historic resources.
Establishes better organization of the community.
Establishes a set of unified corridors of commercial activity wholly within the existing City.
Supports and appropriately develops the downtown district and other existing or emerging
neighborhood commercial districts within the City.
Contribution to a pleasing community character; and
LU Policy 6. Residential and commercial development should be consistent with availability of
LU Policy 8. Opportunities for more development that maximizes green space and common areas
while developing at a density that maximizes efficiency with the incorporated City limits and UGA
should be identified and pursued (Goal 6, Objective 1).
P&R Policy 12. Residential developments should provide open space suitable for recreational
activities and/or connections to existing or proposed City or regional facilities (Goal 3, Objective 3;
It is the opinion of staff that the proposed development is generally consistent with the goals and
policies of the Comprehensive Plan. Additional analysis is provided below on a few of the primary
Density/Type of Use: The type of development proposed is residential, with overall density that is
consistent with surrounding areas. The individual lots (1-19) range in size from 6,000-8,000
square feet, with a density of about 8 lots per acre. This is similar to surrounding developments.
Lot 20 will contain 45 small homes, with a density of about 11 lots per acre. The total number of
residential units that would be allowed under the RM zoning district is 217; the total of 64 units
proposed with this project is obviously well below the maximum level of development that would
be allowed. Additionally, the Applicant does not need to take advantage of the available density
This type of use (residential) and density is consistent with surrounding residential and
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
Infrastructure: Existing infrastructure exists on Lodge Drive and Stevens Street, which the new
roads for this development connect to. The Site Plan Review Committee has reviewed the proposal
to ensure that sufficient infrastructure resources are available. The primary infrastructure concern
raised by the SPRC (and public comment) was related to traffic and road infrastructure. It is the
opinion of staff that these potential impacts can be mitigated, additional information and analysis
Green space/common areas/recreation: There are many Comprehensive Plan policies that frame
the City’s goal to have residential development occur with adequate access to open space and
recreation opportunities. Several of these policies our outlined above. This is also one of the
reasons for allowing planned unit developments, which can enable a property owner to design a
development with increased density and reduced dimensional requirements, in order to provide
additional open space and amenities to residents.
This proposed development will provide some common area improvements, the primary common
area improvement is the proposed pedestrian ways/trails, but a small playground is also proposed.
The development will provide pedestrian access to adjacent areas which will enable residents to
The Site Plan Review Committee (SPRC) reviewed the proposed project for consistency with the
Municipal Code. The results of review are addressed in the attached SPRC Comment Letter dated
ANALYSIS: The SPRC found that the project is generally consistent with the municipal code,
outlining requirements that will have to be met by the applicant. Further analysis regarding key
development standards from the Municipal Code are included below.
Chapter 19.28 provides regulations for planned unit developments. According to Section
19.26.010, “the purpose of the PUD option is to provide greater flexibility and encourage more
design creativity than may be available under conventional standards and development approaches
that comply with the goals and policies of the urban area comprehensive plan.” Section 19.26.010
establishes the following goals for the City’s PUD standards.
A. Promote efficient use of land;
B. Promote efficient and cost-effective extension of public infrastructure;
C. Promote a more efficient street and utility system by clustering units in order to promote
affordable housing, land development and maintenance costs and reduce the amount of
D. Encourage innovative approaches to pedestrian and vehicular circulation within the PUD
which are interconnected to circulation systems surrounding the subject site;
E. Allow flexible, creative and innovative design for difficult sites which preserves existing
natural characteristics of a site such as trees, watercourses and wetlands, topography,
geologic features, and scenic qualities beyond the requirements of the code;
F. Allow for a variety of residential product types and densities;
G. Promote the development of affordable housing to meet the needs of a wide range of
H. Allow for a compatible and complementary mix of residential and nonresidential land uses;
I. Provide appropriate on-site amenities not typically provided in conventional development;
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
J. Allow the clustering of structures to preserve steep slopes and other environmentally
sensitive areas or to create open spaces for the recreational and aesthetic enjoyment of
K. Ensure a design which is compatible with the value, character and integrity of surrounding
areas that have been or are being developed under the urban area comprehensive plan.
Section 19.26.030 outlines components required for planned unit developments, as follows.
A. Common Land. Residential P.U.D.s (including condominiums) shall contain a minimum of
fifteen percent of gross acreage as open space for the common use of residents in the
development. This open land shall be shown on the development plan and permanently
dedicated to the common use. No private or individual use or right shall be assigned or
B. Property Owner’s Association. P.U.D.s include a “Property Owner’s Association” which is an
incorporated, nonprofit corporation to operate under recorded land agreements through
which (a) each property owner in the P.U.D. is a member, and (b) each property is subject to
a charge for a proportionate share of the expenses for the organization’s activities and
C. Common Area Improvements. Common area improvements which may be required to
accomplish the P.U.D. concept may include such facilities as walkways, bicycle paths, tennis
courts, golfing, play apparatus for children, recreation hall, etc., for the benefit of the
residents within the P.U.D. Common areas may also be used to preserve and protect special
environmental features of a site such as streams and adjacent wetlands and other riparian
lands. In such cases, common area improvements may be limited to stream bank restoration
and revegetation to ensure protection of the resource.
ANALYSIS: The proposed development is generally consistent with Chapter 19.26, as stated above.
The proposed planned unit development will provide two housing types: typical single-family lots
and 45 clustered small homes with shared parking and small common areas.
Common Areas/Open Space: The common areas / open space will include pedestrian pathways
throughout the development and a small area with a play structure. A small area at the northeast
corner of the property is part of a buffer for Stone Creek, which is located on an adjacent property.
The Applicant has proposed that the pedestrian walkway that will meander around the backs of the
small homes will be covered with an impervious surface (gravel or wood chip). While there is
nothing specific in the PUD standards about common area improvements or surfacing for
walkways, staff is concerned about maintenance (weeds). The Applicant has stated that they will
be “proactive” to prevent weed growth on the path and would place a weed barrier under the
pathway. The Applicant has met the minimum 15% requirement.
Property Owner’s Association: A property owner’s association must be established before final plat
Other PUD Components: The PUD standards also provide options in WWMC Section 19.26.040,
which enable developments a density bonus and the option to reduce/modify dimensional
standards. The Applicant has chosen not to take advantage of either of these provisions. As
mentioned above, the density will be well below what would be allowed.
The Applicant prepared to reports addressing critical areas: Critical Areas Report dated
12/06/2013 and supplemental letter related to Wetlands.
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
ANALYSIS: The initial critical areas report identified that the following critical areas are located on
site: wetlands; geologically hazardous areas (seismic hazard area, wind erosion susceptibility area);
and fish and wildlife habitat conservation areas (Stone Creek buffer.)
Fish and Wildlife Habitat Conservation Area: Stone Creek is not located on site, it is adjacent.
However, a portion of the required buffer is located on site. The development has been designed to
Wetlands: No wetlands were shown on the National Wetlands Inventory or the City’s critical areas
maps. However, a prior short plat of this property had identified a wetland on this property, called
Wetland B. In 2012, this wetland was found to be about 0.47 acres in size and classified as a
Category III wetland. This wetland was served by an irrigation ditch, which was abandoned
between 2003-2008 and water rights were sold. At that time, the inlet was plugged and it was
intended that 100 percent of the flow into the ditch would be eliminated. Seepage continued into
the ditch and in March/April of 2013 the City repaired the plug to fix this problem. Anderson Perry
concluded that this area no longer meets the definition of a wetland; it no longer displays sufficient
wetland hydrology of hydric soil indicators to be considered a wetland. These reports were
reviewed by David Moore from the Department of Ecology wetlands program. Mr. Moore
concurred with their conclusion and did not require wetland permitting for this project.

text.i: 2. APPROPRIATE PROVISIONS FOR FACTORS ENUMERATED IN RCW 58.17.110

page.text: Staff review resulted in the following findings.
1. Open space – The preliminary plat and planned unit development designates open space
common areas for the proposed subdivision.
2. Drainage ways – No known drainage ways or streams are located on-site. Existing
stormwater facilities will be maintained and utilized for the proposed subdivision.
3. Streets, roads, alleys and other public ways – Sufficient streets are proposed to provide
access and accommodate the needs of the residents within the proposed project.
4. Transit stops –The project is of insufficient density to require transit stops within the
5. Potable water & sanitary sewer – The project will be served by City water and sewer.
6. Parks, recreation & playgrounds –The applicant will establish common areas within the
development to provide recreation (walking and playground) opportunities for residents of
7. Sidewalks and other planning features for walking to and from school – Sidewalks and other
pedestrian walkways will be provided which connect to adjacent streets.
3. ADEQUATE MEANS OF INGRESS AND EGRESS
Staff has determined, after review by the SPRC and City Engineering, that there is adequate means
for ingress and egress to all lots within the proposed subdivision. Additional information is
included in the Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) and the City of Walla Walla Engineering Divisions. As
proposed, all roads will be private.
Traffic Impacts: Traffic impacts were evaluated a TIA prepared by J-U-B Engineers. The analysis
concluded that when the anticipated traffic from this development is added to existing traffic
volumes for the year 2018, all intersections will function with acceptable Levels of Service except
the intersection of Tietan Street/Third Avenue, which will have an average vehicle delay of 42
seconds for a Level of Service of “F.” The Analysis further concludes that this development would
contribute 3% of the anticipated traffic at this intersection and so the Applicant should be required
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
to contribute 3% of the cost of a traffic signal at this intersection. This cost is estimated to be
4. MITIGATION OF PROBABLE ADVERSE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS
As noted above, review was completed under the State Environmental Policy Act and a
Determination of Non-Significance (DNS) was issued. It was determined that no mitigation is
necessary to address potential environmental impacts. Walla Walla Municipal Code and State
Staff review of the application for shoreline substantial development permit resulted in the
1. The applicant met with City of Walla Walla SPRC and Walla Walla Joint Community
Development Agency (WWJCDA) staff on several occasions for pre-submittal meetings in
2. A Notice of Application was published in the Walla Walla Union Bulletin, posted on-site,
mailed to surrounding property owners, and posted on the WWJCDA website with a
3. The application was reviewed by the City of Walla Walla Site Plan Review Committee on
January 9, 2014 for compliance with application City standards, regulations, and policies.
The committee provided a summary of their review in a letter dated February 5, 2014;
4. Application materials were distributed to local and state agencies for review including
Walla Walla Public Schools, the Washington State Department of Ecology and the members
of the City’s Site Plan Review Committee;
5. The City of Walla Walla SEPA Responsible Official, WWJCDA Director Tom Glover, issued a
final Determination of Non-Significance (DNS) on February 13, 2014;
6. A Notice of Public Hearing was mailed to surrounding property owners, posted at City Hall,
and posted on the WWJCDA website.
7. The proposal is in conformance with the goals and policies of the Walla Walla Urban Area
8. The proposed use and corresponding preliminary plat and planned unit development plan
have been designed in accordance with the permitted uses within the Residential land use
designation and standards for development set forth in the City’s development regulations
if approved subject to the recommended conditions stated in this staff report;
9. Public facilities, such as roads, sewer and water are adequate to support the use and layout
of the proposed planned unit development if developed in accordance with the
recommended conditions contained in this staff report; and
Following presentation of the above staff report, the following procedure is outlined for the
DISCUSSION of the proposal with staff
Oath administered to all those who intend to testify
Sunset Lodge North – Preliminary Subdivision PUD (P13-092)
WWMC 20.27.050(D): “The reviewing body shall, following the public hearing, forward its
recommendation to the city council to approve, deny or approve with such conditions as are
necessary to bring the proposal to conformance with the standards of this code and policies of the
Comprehensive Plan. Conditions of approval may include actions necessary to avoid imposition of
undue public service obligations on the city, or mitigation of detrimental effects on other property
owners. Conditions of approval shall be based on the standard or policy which permits or requires
Staff recommends to the Planning Commission that a recommendation of approval of the proposed
preliminary plat/planned unit development request, File Number P13-092, be made to City Council
Staff recommends the following conditions of approval.
1. The Applicant must comply with the Site Plan Review Committee letter dated 02/05/2014.
2. The property owner’s association agreement/covenants must include provisions to
maintain the impervious walkways as weed-free.
3. The Applicant must pay 3% of the cost to improve the intersection of Third Avenue and
Tietan Street, pursuant to the Traffic Impact Analysis.
F. Title Report/Short Plat Certificate dated 08/26/2013
J. Notice of Application / ODNS for mailing dated 12/27/2013
K. Notice of Application / ODNS for posting and publishing dated 12/27/2013
L. Notice of Application / ODNS certificate and mailing list
M. Site Plan Review Committee summary letter dated 02/05/2014
O. SEPA Determination of Non-Significance (DNS) dated 02/13/2014
Q. Notice of Public Hearing certificate and mailing list
R. Public Comments – email from Carol McCormmach dated 01/13/2014
S. Letter from Department of Ecology dated 01/10/2014
T. Email from David Moore, Department of Ecology, dated 01/16/2014
U. Memo from City of Walla Walla Engineering Division dated 01/15/2014
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-13-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
Appendix B – Level of Service Worksheets
Appendix C – Sunset Lodge North Preliminary Plat Concept
Appendix D - SR 125/Plaza Way/9th Avenue/Dallas Military Road Conceptual Intersection Improvements
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
The southern portion of the City of Walla Walla, Washington has various parcels that remain
undeveloped within the Urban Growth Boundary. One of these parcels is 7.42 acres situated south of
Tietan Street and east of Stevens Street and is zoned as R-72 – Single Family Residential. Hayden Homes
is pursuing developing the parcel as a Planned Unit Development (PUD). The proposed PUD
development has 19 single family lots and 44 single family residential homes that range in size from 400
SF to 1064 SF. The small homes are a part of the Hayden Homes product line called Wisesize. They are
meant to accommodate singles, couples or small families and be an alternative to apartment living.
In order to ensure that the transportation network can accommodate the trips generated by
development proposals, the City of Walla Walla requires that a Traffic Impact Analysis be performed. At
the direction of City of Walla Walla staff, this Traffic Impact Analysis has been performed to forecast and
evaluate the PM peak hour for the 5 year horizon to ensure that acceptable LOS can be provided in the
short term for concurrency at four intersections:
The city has previously recognized poor levels of service at the SR 125/Plaza Way intersection and has
conceptual improvements identified to achieve acceptable Levels of Service. To ensure that the
improvements identified will indeed provide acceptable LOS for the 20 year horizon and evaluation of
This study will summarize existing conditions, future traffic operational conditions in 2018 and 2033
without the development, as well as future conditions with the proposed 63 residential units and any
mitigation that may be necessary to provide acceptable Levels of Service in order to meet City
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
This section will document existing conditions with respect to land use, roadway characteristics, traffic
volumes and traffic operations at the study intersections.
The proposed PUD lies approximately one mile south of downtown Walla Walla, Washington. To the
south and east of the project site is developed residential. North of Tietan Street is the Walla Walla
County Fairgrounds. Immediately to the west is undeveloped while further west are commercial
developments including the Plaza Shopping Center. South of the proposed development is also
residential but includes significant undeveloped lands as well.
Roadways are described below, while the lane geometry for study intersections and existing PM peak
hour traffic volumes are shown in Figure 1.
Tietan Street is an east-west minor arterial that connects Plaza Way on the west to Fern Avenue on the
east approximately 1.5 miles in length. It has one travel lane in each direction with intermittent
sidewalks, some parallel parking and turn lanes at major intersections. The speed limit is 30 MPH. East
and west of Third Avenue Tietan Street is slightly off-set, causing the intersection geometry to include
east-west right turn lanes as opposed to exclusive left turn lanes, which affects the capacity of the
Plaza Way is a north-south minor arterial roadway that has two lanes in each direction except for the
southbound direction between SR 125 and Tietan Street where a single southbound lane exists. Plaza
Way has curb, gutter and sidewalks, and has a posted speed limit of 30 MPH.
SR 125 is a north-south principal arterial roadway and is also known as 9
Avenue in the City of Walla
Walla. It has 2 travel lanes in each direction. North of Plaza Way it has a two-way left-turn lane and a
speed limit of 30 MPH. South of Plaza way it has a raised center median and a speed limit of 55 MPH.
Dallas Military Road is a two lane minor arterial roadway with a speed limit of 30 MPH. It has curb,
gutter and sidewalk in the study area.
Third Avenue is a collector roadway that has a single lane in each direction with turn lanes at major
intersections. North of Tietan Street there are no sidewalks while south of Tietan Street sidewalks, curb
and gutter exist. The posted speed ranges from 25 to 30 MPH.
Stevens Street is a two lane local street. It has curb, gutter and sidewalk south of Tietan Street to the
frontage of the proposed development. The speed limit is 25 MPH.
Manual turning movement counts were collected from 4:00 – 6:00 PM at the four study intersections on
November 14, 2013, and are included in Appendix A. The peak hour occurred from 4:30 – 5:30 PM. It
was learned that the intersection of Dallas Military Road/Myra Road west of the study area was closed
for construction activities. The traffic volumes collected as part of this effort were compared with
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
volumes collected in 2010 for development near Plaza Way/Tietan Street and discussed with City staff.
City staff indicated that it that at the SR 125/Plaza Way/Dallas Military Road intersection that certain
movements would likely be affected by the construction. City staff noted that all-day traffic volumes
collected in 2013 were lower than previous counts as well. In fact, nearly all movements were
significantly lower than previous counts, with the overall volume at the intersection being over 9% lower
than the 2010 volumes. A comparison was also made at the intersection of Plaza Way/Tietan Street and
it was found that overall traffic volumes were approximately 6% lower than the 2010 PM peak hour
volumes. As such, it was determined that a more reasonable estimate of traffic volumes at SR
125/Plaza Way would be the volumes collected in 2010 but adjusted down 5% to correspond with the
volumes at Plaza Way/Tietan. The traffic volumes collected in November 2013 at the three intersections
on Tietan Street and the adjusted volumes at SR 125/Plaza Way are shown in Figure 1 along with the
existing lane configurations at the study intersections.
The analysis of Level-of-Service (LOS) is a means of quantitatively describing the quality of operational
conditions of a roadway segment or intersection and the perception by motorists and passengers.
Service levels are identified by letter designation, A – F, with LOS “A” representing the best operating
conditions and LOS “F” the worst. Each LOS represents a range of operating conditions and one or more
Measures Of Effectiveness (MOE’s) are used to quantify the LOS of a roadway element. For intersections
the MOE used is average control delay in seconds per vehicle. While there are several methodologies
for estimating the LOS of intersections, the most commonly used is presented in the Highway Capacity
Manual and is the methodology used in this study (HCM 2010). The Highway Capacity Manual LOS
criteria for intersections are summarized in Table 1.

text.b: Table 1. Level of Service Criteria for Intersections

page.text: Source: Highway Capacity Manual 2010, Transportation Research Board,
For unsignalized intersections “delay” is based on the availability of gaps in the major street to allow
minor street movements to occur. The methodology prioritizes each movement at an unsignalized
intersection consistent with rules that govern right-of-way for drivers. In other words major street
through and right turn traffic has absolute priority over all other movements. Major street left turns
must yield to opposing through traffic and right turns. Minor street through traffic and right turns yield
to major street higher priority movements, and the minor street left turns have the lowest priority and
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
must yield to all other movements. As traffic volumes increase, the availability of gaps will decrease and
greater delay tends to result in driver frustration and anxiety, loss of time, unnecessary fuel
consumption, and contributes to unnecessary air pollution. The City of Walla Walla has adopted the
standard for Level of Service as LOS “D” for intersections, meaning the overall intersection LOS must be
Peak hour traffic volumes and existing intersection geometry were input into Synchro Software to
determine the delay and Level of Service at the study intersections. The results of the capacity analysis
are shown in Table 2 below with LOS worksheet calculations included in Appendix B.
The existing conditions analysis indicates that overall delay and LOS for the study intersections is
acceptable with all intersections currently functioning at LOS “C” or better during the PM peak hour.
Avenue to Plaza Way has the highest average vehicle delay at 67
seconds and LOS “E”, but the overall approach is LOS C because the delay for the southbound through
movement has a higher volume of traffic and only 16 seconds of delay.

text.b: Table 2. Existing (2013) Delay and Level of Service

page.text: Sunset Lodge North Traffic Impact Analysis
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
This section evaluates traffic volumes at the study intersections for future conditions with and without the
No major changes in land use or the roadway network are expected within the 5-year planning horizon.
For the purposes of this study it is anticipated that for the 2018 No-build conditions no changes to the
existing roadway network will be in place.
As is typical with most traffic studies, a growth rate for background traffic is used to apply to existing
traffic volumes to account for growth in traffic that is the result of development outside the study area.
For this study, at the direction of the City of Walla Walla staff, even though recent years have shown a
decline in traffic volumes at some study intersections and in order to be conservatively high, a 1.5% per
year growth rate was applied to each movement to account for background growth at the four study
intersections to estimate year 2018 traffic volumes without the proposed development. The resulting
2018 No-Build traffic volumes are shown in Figure 2.
The traffic volumes from Figure 2 and existing lane configurations and traffic control were evaluated for
delay and Level of Service. The results are shown in Table 3 and LOS worksheets are again included in
Appendix B. The analysis indicates that delay will increase at each intersection with the LOS at SR
125/Plaza Way falling to LOS “D”, and both of the intersections of Tietan Street at Plaza Way and
Stevens Street anticipated to continue to function at LOS “C” but the unsignalized intersection of Tietan
Street/ Third Avenue falling to LOS E with an average of 38.1 seconds of average vehicle delay for the
southbound approach. With a traffic signal installed at the intersection of Tietan Street/Third Avenue
the intersection will improve to overall LOS “B” with the westbound approach being the worst at LOS
The Planned Unit Development (PUD) of Sunset Lodge in Walla Walla, Washington is proposed by
Hayden Homes to be situated east of Stevens Street, north of Lodge Drive, west of Sunset Street and
south of Tietan Street. It includes 19 single family lots with an additional 44 single family units in the
PUD that share 110 parking stalls as well as common areas. The 44 single family units range in size from
400 SF to 1064 SF. The small homes are a part of the Hayden Homes product line called Wisesize. They
are meant to accommodate singles, couples or small families and be an alternative to apartment living.
Access to the site will be via Stevens Street to Tietan Street and Lodge Drive to Third Avenue.
The Conceptual Design is included in Appendix C.
In order to determine the number of PM peak hour trips anticipated to be generated by the
development, the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation Manual was consulted.
This is a nationally recognized compilation of trip generation rates for common land uses. Although the
proposed development is an alternative to apartment living, due to the amount of parking to be
provided it is anticipated that it will function more like single family residences and thus the rates for
single family residential were used for this analysis. The trip generation rate for Land Use 210 indicates
an average weekday trip generation for 63 single family units to be 9.52 trips per unit for a total of 600
average weekday trips, with an average of 1 trip per unit during the PM peak hour (64% inbound and
36% outbound) for 40 inbound and 23 outbound trips for the proposed PUD.

text.b: Table 3. 2018 No-Build Scenario Delay and Level of Service

page.text: Sunset Lodge North Traffic Impact Analysis
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
The new PM peak hour trips were added to the roadway network and study intersections using the
existing traffic patterns at study intersections. In order to reflect a worst case scenario at the
intersection of Tietan Street/Stevens Street, all trips were assigned to that intersection. In reality
however, trips destined to the south would travel east on Lodge Drive rather than Tietan Street to go
south of Third Avenue. Trips destined to go north on Third Avenue will find it easier to go north on
Stevens Street and make a right turn on Tietan Street and then a left turn on Third Avenue rather than
Lodge Drive east to go north on Third Avenue to the stop sign at Tietan Street.
The resulting trip distribution percentages are shown in Figure 3, with the Sunset Lodge trips shown in
Figure 4. The trips shown in Figure 4 were added to the 2018 No-Build volumes shown in Figure 2 to
produce the 2018 Build Scenario traffic volumes that are shown in Figure 5.
Capacity analysis was again performed for the study intersections using the traffic volumes existing lane
configurations and traffic control shown in Figure 5. The results of the capacity analysis are shown in
Table 4, with the detailed worksheets included in Appendix B.
As shown in Table 4, the 2018 delays with the proposed PUD will result in similar delay and LOS as
shown for the 2018 No-Build scenario. The two unsignalized intersection on Tietan Street are
anticipated to have an additional delay of 3 seconds per vehicle during the PM peak hour for the minor
street approaches. This will continue to result in unacceptable LOS at the intersection of Teitan
Street/Third Avenue. Similar mitigation as the No-Build Scenario including a traffic signal will be
required in order to achieve acceptable Levels of Service. The two signalized intersections will continue
The Sunset Lodge PUD is forecast to contribute 35 trips to the Tietan Street/Third Avenue intersection of
a total 1,174 vehicles at the intersection for 3% of the total. The development should contribute 3% of
the cost of the installation of a traffic signal as mitigation for traffic impacts associated with the
development. Planning level cost estimates for a traffic signal are in the range of $250,000, 3% of which

text.b: Table 4. 2018 Build Scenario Delay and Level of Service

page.text: Sunset Lodge North Traffic Impact Analysis
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
At the request of the City of Walla Walla staff, an evaluation of the study intersections was performed
for the 20 year horizon as well, with and without the proposed Sunset Lodge PUD.
Population and employment growth in the Walla Walla region will no doubt influence traffic volumes
and traffic patterns. The City has identified intersection improvements at the intersection of SR
125/Plaza Way/Dallas Military Road to address delay and capacity issues at that intersection. These
a second southbound left turn lane from SR 125 to Plaza Way that would require a second
southbound through lane on Plaza Way from SR 125 to south of Tietan Street
additional northbound approach lane that would create an exclusive left turn lane and provide
improved traffic signal operations by eliminating the split-phasing of the traffic signal for Plaza
The conceptual improvement is included in Appendix D. The city has also identified long-range network
improvements that would connect Taumarson Road southwest of the study area to connect to SR 125 at
Myra Road. Since no funding has yet been identified for either of these improvements, no changes in
the lane configurations were included in the initial 2033 No-Build Scenario analysis.
A 0.5% per year growth rate was applied to each movement at the four study intersections to account
for additional background growth to estimate year 2033 traffic volumes without the proposed
development. The resulting 2033 No-Build traffic volumes are shown in Figure 6.
The traffic volumes from Figure 6 and existing lane configurations and traffic control were evaluated for
delay and Level of Service. Signalized intersections were optimized, meaning total delay minimized
through signal phasing. This sometimes can create excessive delay for some movements. The results of
the analysis are shown in Table 5 and LOS worksheets are again included in Appendix B.
The analysis indicates that overall delay will increase at the SR 125/Plaza Way intersection to more than
49 seconds of average vehicle day but the northbound and eastbound approaches will function at an
unacceptable LOS of “E” with 64 and 70 seconds of delay respectively. The intersection of Tietan
Street/Third Avenue will fall to LOS “F” for both of the minor street approaches, the southbound being
thee worst at over 82 seconds of average vehicle delay. The other two intersections of Tietan Street at
Plaza Way and Stevens Street are anticipated to function at LOS “C”.
The improvement discussed above that adds a second southbound left turn lane from SR 125 to Plaza
Way and an exclusive northbound left turn lane will significantly improve the traffic operations at the
intersection, reducing delay by more than 25 seconds per vehicle with each approach functioning at LOS
“C” or better. According to the analysis however, some of that delay is shifted to the Plaza Way
intersection at Tietan Street as vehicles will arrive their more quickly and the delay is spread around the
intersection for approximately an additional 1.5 seconds of delay, but maintaining overall LOS of “C”.
The intersection of Tietan Street/Third Avenue will require traffic signalization in order to achieve
acceptable Levels of Service. With the traffic signal in place and the existing lane configurations at that
location, LOS “B” will be provided on three approaches with the westbound expected to operate at LOS

text.b: Table 5. 2033 No-Build Scenario Delay and Level of Service

page.text: Sunset Lodge North Traffic Impact Analysis
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
The anticipated trips for the Sunset Lodge PUD described earlier in the 2018 Build Scenario section and
shown in Figure 4, totaling 40 inbound and 23 outbound trips, were added to the 2033 No-Build
volumes shown in Figure 6 to estimate the 2033 Build Scenario PM peak hour traffic volumes and are
Capacity analysis was again performed for the study intersections using the traffic volumes existing lane
configurations and traffic control shown in Figure 7. The results of the capacity analysis are shown in
Table 6, with the detailed worksheets included in Appendix B.
Similar LOS results as the 2033 No-Build analysis were obtained, with an additional second of delay at
the two existing signalized intersections on Plaza Way. The improvements described above in the No-
Build discussion will improve conditions such that acceptable LOS of “C” will be achieved at both
intersections. Since these improvements are beyond the 6 year requirement for concurrency no
mitigation contribution is required but the analysis does show that the improvements identified by the
city will be effective at achieving acceptable Levels of Service in the long-range.
The additional vehicles at the two unsignalized intersections on Tietan Street result in an additional 5 – 7
seconds of delay for the minor street approaches. The intersection of Tietan Street/Stevens Street is
predicted to fall to LOS “D”, which is still acceptable, while the Tietan Street/Third Avenue will be LOS
“F” similar to the 2033 No-Build scenario and will require installation of a traffic signal to achieve an
acceptable LOS. With the traffic signal installed, and the existing intersection lane configuration, the
intersection is anticipated to have overall LOS of “C” with 3 of the approaches functioning at LOS “B”.

text.b: Table 6. 2033 Build Scenario Delay and Level of Service

page.text: Sunset Lodge North Traffic Impact Analysis
J-U-B Engineers, Inc. |30-12-083/Sunset Lodge North TIA 12-11-13.docx
Hayden Homes has proposed a Planned Unit Development on a 7.42 acre parcel situated south of Tietan
Street and east of Stevens Street. The proposed PUD development has 19 single family lots and 44
single family residential homes that range in size from 400 SF to 1064 SF. The small homes are a part of
the Hayden Homes product line called Wisesize. They are meant to accommodate singles, couples or
small families and be an alternative to apartment living.
In order to ensure that the transportation network can accommodate the trips generated by
development proposals, the City of Walla Walla required that this Traffic Impact Analysis be performed
to forecast and evaluate the PM peak hour for the 5 year horizon to ensure that acceptable LOS can be
provided in the short term for concurrency at four intersections: 9
Road/Plaza Way (SR 125/Plaza Way), Tietan Street/Plaza Way, Tietan Street/Stevens Street, Tietan
The city has previously recognized poor levels of service at the SR 125/Plaza Way intersection and has
conceptual improvements identified to achieve acceptable Levels of Service. To ensure that the
improvements identified will indeed provide acceptable LOS for the 20 year horizon and evaluation of
The proposed PUD is anticipated to generation 600 average weekday trips and 63 PM peak hour trips
(40 inbound and 23 outbound). When added to the existing traffic volumes at the study intersections
for the year 2018 it was shown that all intersections will function with acceptable Levels of Service
except the intersection of Tietan Street/Third Avenue which will have an average vehicle delay of 42
seconds for LOS “F”. A traffic signal would be required in order to achieve acceptable Levels of Service
and would provide LOS “B” for the intersection overall, with 3 approaches being LOS”B” and the
westbound approach anticipated to function at LOS “C” with the existing lane configuration and a new
The Sunset Lodge PUD is forecast to contribute 35 trips to the Tietan Street/Third Avenue intersection
3% of the total (1,174) in 2018. The development should contribute 3% of the cost of the installation of
a traffic signal as mitigation for traffic impacts associated with the development. Planning level cost
estimates for a traffic signal are in the range of $250,000, 3% of which would amount to $7,500.
The year 2033 analysis indicates that the intersection of SR 125/Plaza Way will require improvements
with or without the proposed development as multiple approaches will function at LOS “E”. With the
conceptual improvements identified by the City that would include a second southbound left turn lane
from SR 125 to Plaza Way and carried south on Plaza Way through Tietan Street, as well as an exclusive
westbound left turn lane from Plaza Way to SR 125that would allow the elimination of the east-west
split signal phasing, the intersection would function at LOS “C” overall with 3 approaches at LOS “C” and
one approach at LOS “D”. Since these improvements are beyond the 6-year concurrency requirement
no mitigation contribution is required but the analysis does show that the improvements identified by
the city will achieve acceptable LOS in the long term.
The intersection of Tietan Street/Third Avenue will be LOS “F” in 2033 with or without the development
and will require installation of a traffic signal to achieve an acceptable LOS. With the traffic signal
installed, and the existing intersection lane configuration, the intersection is anticipated to have overall
LOS of “C”, with 3 of the approaches functioning at LOS “B”.

text.b: Sunset Lodge North Preliminary Plat Concept
